fill: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));
fill: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));
fill: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

rect.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 230, 204), rgb(54, 33, 10)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(215, 155, 0), rgb(153, 101, 0));

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 118px; height: 1px; padding-top: 540px; margin-left: 1px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center; color: #000000;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

rect.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 242, 204), rgb(40, 29, 0)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(214, 182, 86), rgb(109, 81, 0));

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 708px; height: 1px; padding-top: 30px; margin-left: 61px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center; color: #000000;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.p: - NumPy (Numerical Python) provides an efficient interface to store and operate on dense data arrays.
- Numpy is fast because its written in C and is strictly typed i.e. all items in the array has a same type and its defined.

switch.text: - NumPy (Numerical Python) provides an efficient interface to store and operate on dense data arrays....

rect.style: fill: light-dark(#ffffff, var(--ge-dark-color, #121212)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 698px; height: 1px; padding-top: 225px; margin-left: 202px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left; color: #000000;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.span: - multi-dimension: Shape(a,b,c,d). Here array has 'a' items. Each 'a' item has 'b' items. Each 'b' item has 'c' items. And so on

div.font: - 2D: special case. Shape(row,column). First dimension/axis is called 'row'

rect.style: fill: light-dark(#ffffff, var(--ge-dark-color, #121212)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 698px; height: 1px; padding-top: 340px; margin-left: 202px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left; color: #000000;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.font: - Similar syntax to the python list.

font.font: - Negative step value: Reverse the start and stop value.

div.font: - Unlike python list slicing, array slice return "views" rather than "copies" of the array data. This means that if we modify sub-array, then the original array will change.
- `x2[:2, :2].copy()`: This creates copy rather than a view. Modifying this won't change the original array.

rect.style: fill: light-dark(#ffffff, var(--ge-dark-color, #121212)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 698px; height: 1px; padding-top: 445px; margin-left: 202px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left; color: #000000;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.font:
Change the shape. It
works when the size of initial array matches the size of reshaped array.

span.font: All the input array dimensions except for the concatenation axis must match exactly. By default, concatenation happens along first axis (axis=0) i.e. (2,3) + (2,3) = (4,3)
np.split(x, [a,b..n]) returns N+1 subarrays - [[0 to a-1], [a to b-1], ...[n to last item]]

switch.text: - Reshaping: Change the shape. It works when the size of initial array matches the size of reshaped array....

path.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

rect.style: fill: light-dark(#ffffff, var(--ge-dark-color, #121212)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 698px; height: 1px; padding-top: 540px; margin-left: 202px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left; color: #000000;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.font: - Vectorized operation: Simply perform operation on array, which will then be applied to each element. They are fast.
div.div: - Vectorized operations are performed via NumPy 'universal' functions (ufuncs).
- Example: `x + 5` -> '+' operator is a wrapper round `np.add()`

rect.style: fill: light-dark(#ffffff, var(--ge-dark-color, #121212)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 698px; height: 1px; padding-top: 130px; margin-left: 202px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left; color: #000000;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.font: - are homogeneous i.e. all elements within the array must have the same data
- when creating array - if types do not match, numpy will upcast if possible (e.g. integers are upcasted to floats)
- when updating array - numpy will downcast without raising any warning (e.g. floating value is truncated in an integer array)

rect.style: fill: light-dark(#ffffff, var(--ge-dark-color, #121212)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 698px; height: 1px; padding-top: 640px; margin-left: 262px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left; color: #000000;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Multidimensional aggregates:
- By default, aggregation function will return the aggregate over the entire array
- `x.min(axis=0)`: minimum value within each column; `x.min(axis=1)`: minimum value within each row
- NOTE: here the 'axis' keyword specifies the dimension of the array that will be collapsed, rather than the dimension that will be returned

rect.style: fill: light-dark(#ffffff, var(--ge-dark-color, #121212)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 698px; height: 1px; padding-top: 773px; margin-left: 202px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left; color: #000000;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Broadcasting:
- It is set of rules for binary uFunc on arrays of different sizes.
-
Rules:
Rule 1: If the two arrays differ in their number of dimensions, the shape of the one with fewer dimensions is padded with ones on its leading (left) side. E.g. (2, 3) & (3,) streches/broadcast to (2, 3) & (1, 3)
Rule 2: If the shape of the two arrays does not match in any dimension, the array with shape equal to 1 in that dimension is stretched to match the other shape.
E.g. (1, 3) & (3, 1) streches/broadcast to (3, 3) & (3, 3)
Rule 3: If in any dimension the sizes disagree and neither is equal to 1, an error is raised. E.g. (3, 2) & (3, 3) -> Error

rect.style: fill: light-dark(#ffffff, var(--ge-dark-color, #121212)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 698px; height: 1px; padding-top: 895px; margin-left: 202px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left; color: #000000;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Boolean Mask:
- Select all values in positions where the mask array is 'True'
- Returns 1D array
- `x[x < 5]`. O/P => 'array([0, 3, 3, 3, 2, 4])'

rect.style: fill: light-dark(#ffffff, var(--ge-dark-color, #121212)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 698px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1030px; margin-left: 202px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left; color: #000000;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Fancy Indexing:
- Fancy indexing is like the simple indexing, but we pass arrays of indices in place of single scalars, allowing to quickly access and modify SUNSETS of an array’s values.
- simple indices (e.g., arr[0]), slices (e.g., arr[:5]), and Boolean masks (e.g., arr[arr > 0]).
- fancy indices: arr[1D array or multi-D array]
- With fancy indexing, the shape of the result reflects the broadcasted shape of the index arrays rather than the shape of the array being indexed
- The pairing of indices in multi-dimensional array in fancy indexing follows the broadcasting rules
- NOTE: When modifying value, repeated indices can cause some potentially unexpected result

rect.style: fill: light-dark(#ffffff, var(--ge-dark-color, #121212)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left; color: #000000;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Sort:
- `np.sort(x)`, `np.argsort(x)`
- partial sorts: `np.partition(X, k)` returns a new array with the smallest K values to the left of the partition, and the remaining values to the right, in arbitrary order
